journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Flow regime effects over non-cavitating diesel injection nozzles

contrib-group.aff: CMT-Motores Térmicos, Universidad Politécnica de Valencia, Valencia, Spain

author-notes.corresp: *CMT-Motores Térmicos, Universidad Politécnica de Valencia, Camino de Vera s/n, Valencia E-46022, Spain. email: jaigigar@mot.upv.es

abstract.p: The research conducted and explained in this paper aims to explore and understand the influence of flow regime (laminar, transition or turbulent) inside diesel injector nozzles. For this purpose, an experimental study based on mass flow rate and momentum flux measurements on three convergent nozzles has been carried out. The combination of both types of measurement has been helpful to obtain information about the nature of the flow and its consequences on important variables, such as injection effective velocity and effective area of nozzle outlet orifices. As a main result of the investigation, and depending of the flow regime, a differentiated behaviour has been observed which was clearly reflected in the non-dimensional flow parameters defined and used through the study.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, injection system research has been a focus of great interest in the diesel engine framework. Considering a mixing controlled combustion, the air–fuel mixing process governs mainly the engine performance and pollutant emissions; therefore, the above mentioned interest is not accidental, as the quality of the air–fuel mixture will largely depend on the proper working of the injection system [1–4].

Before improving the injection system performance it is necessary to deeply understand all the phenomena involved. Undoubtedly, one of the most critical elements on this process is the injection nozzle and, more specifically, the geometry of the discharge outlets. This geometry will influence the characteristics of internal flow and spray development [4–7].

However, despite the influence of the flow characteristics inside the injection orifices on the injection and combustion processes, the physics of this flow is currently unknown. This lack of knowledge is partly justified by the enormous difficulty of studying the internal flow: the small size of the orifices, the high flow velocities and the strongly transient flow. These features make the experimental study of the flow inside the orifices of the injection nozzles quite complicated [4].

Improvements in nozzle manufacturing techniques have made it possible to use convergent orifices with the aim of preventing cavitation [8], as well as improving the discharge coefficient. In recent years, engine manufacturers have chosen these convergent nozzles in preference to cylindrical and cavitating ones. Convergent nozzles offer more consistent and predictable behaviour independent of the pressure conditions used in the engine operating map. These trends do not apply to cylindrical nozzles where different pressure can lead to cavitation at some points and no cavitation at other ones, generating diverse situations depending on the cavitation appearance and leading to a completely different flow behaviour at the orifice outlet with an effective area much smaller in the case of cavitating conditions [9].

As a first approach, and because of the high velocities and high Reynolds numbers inside injection nozzles in diesel injection conditions, it is reasonable to think that the flow would always be turbulent even for low injection pressures. However, as discussed in this work, this hypothesis is not always correct, and there can exist points at low injection pressure conditions where the flow is not turbulent, therefore affecting both internal flow characteristics and subsequent spray development. This must be taken into consideration when an injection nozzle is designed or injection mapping is set up for a given engine, even more so given that diesel injection nozzles are becoming smaller and more convergent.

This work is focused on revealing the effects of the flow regime on nozzle internal flow. For this purpose, the experimental study uses three convergent nozzles with different diameters and different pressure conditions, on which is measured not only the mass flow but also the momentum flux. The great interest of both measurements, mass and momentum flux, is the possibility of estimating parameters such as velocity and effective area at the nozzle outlet and the dimensionless coefficients [9]. Using these parameters, it can be determined which is the flow regime at each tested point, and it is also possible to determine at each case the effect of regime type on flow characteristics. Moreover, the study of three different nozzles allows the influence of the orifice diameter size to be determined, or the influence of the length–diameter ratio, on the regime and the internal flow behaviour.

The current paper is divided into three parts. In the first part, theoretical aspects of flow are discussed, with the definition of different flow parameters used (section 2). In the second part the experimental techniques employed are briefly presented (section 3), and the nozzles and operating conditions tested (section 4). In the last part, the obtained results are presented (section 5), and the analysis is performed (section 6).

sec.title: 2.1 Mass and momentum flux
sec.p: The mass flux through the outlet section of an injection orifice (see Fig. (1a)), can be obtained as

ρ

In the same way, the momentum flux through the outlet section of an injection orifice, and considering only the axial component, can be obtained as

with
M
·
being the axial component of the momentum flux at the orifice outlet.

sec.title: 2.2 Effective velocity and area
sec.p: From the mass and momentum flux measurements it is possible to determine two useful internal flow parameters: effective velocity and effective area at orifice outlet.

The real flow at the orifice outlet will be determined by the profiles of velocity and density, (see Fig. 1(a)). In this flow, it is possible to measure, and therefore to know, both momentum and mass flux, as the integral, according to equations (1) and (2).

The characteristics of these profiles are totally unknown. However, it is possible to define an effective velocity and area representatives of the flow. The definition of these parameters is based on a simplified flow, which is characterized by an effective area
A
eff
, lower than the geometric one, through the flow goes out with an uniform effective velocity
u
eff
, and with a density equal to the liquid one
ρ
f
(see Fig. 1(b)). Moreover, the value of these parameters,
u
eff
and
A
eff
, must be such that the mass and momentum flux for the simplified flow (Fig. 1(b)) will be equal to the real situation (Fig. 1(a)).
Solving the integral equations of mass and momentum flux ((1) and (2)) for the simplified case we obtain
From these two equations it is possible to obtain the effective velocity and area, as function of the mass and momentum flux, which are known as
Moreover, if a circular area is supposed, we can obtain the effective diameter as

sec.title: 2.3 Maximum theoretical Bernoulli velocity
sec.p: The Bernoulli velocity represents the maximum theoretical velocity that can be achieved in the nozzle orifice outlet, for a given pressure drop. In order to evaluate it, the Bernoulli equation between upstream and downstream of the orifice is used. Thus, assuming negligible upstream velocity and no losses between upstream and downstream, we have

where
p
i
and
p
b
are upstream or injection pressure and downstream or back pressure respectively, and
ρ
f
is the fuel density. Isolating from this equation, and taking into account that the pressure drop at the orifice is
Δ p =
p
i
−
p
b
, the maximum theoretical velocity, also known as Bernoulli velocity, is defined as

sec.title: 2.4 Flow coefficients
sec.p: In this section, the dimensionless coefficients of the above parameters: mass flux, momentum flux, effective velocity, and effective area, will be defined.

sec.title: Velocity coefficient
sec.p: This coefficient relates the effective velocity with the maximum theoretical Bernoulli velocity (equation (9)). It is calculated with the equation

sec.title: Area coefficient
sec.p: This coefficient is used for evaluating the reduction of the effective area with respect to the geometric one, and it is calculated as

sec.title: Discharge coefficient
sec.p: This coefficient is defined as the real measured mass flux with respect to the maximum theoretical mass flux [10]. The maximum mass flux is evaluated considering a uniform velocity equal to the Bernoulli velocity and using all the geometric section area

sec.title: Momentum coefficient
sec.p: As in the mass flux, the momentum coefficient is defined as the real measured momentum flux with respect to the maximum theoretical momentum flux, where the maximum momentum flux is evaluated considering the Bernoulli velocity and the geometric area

sec.title: 2.4.1 Relations between coefficients
sec.p:
If in the
C
d
coefficient, equation (12), mass flux is replaced with effective parameters, this obtains
Combining this equation with equations (11) and (10), we obtain
Operating as above, the momentum coefficient is obtained as
Finally, combining this two relations obtains

sec.title: 2.5 Flow parameter interpretation
sec.p:
The area coefficient,
C
a
, is used to evaluate the losses of effective section area with respect to the geometric area. The lower the
C
a
, the bigger area losses. The losses of effective area are due to the following possible causes:

list-item.p: non-uniform velocity profile at orifice outlet;
cavitation cavities reaching the orifice outlet;

sec.p:
Considering these causes, it is expected that a fully developed turbulent flow without cavitation will have
C
a
≈ 1
due to its uniform velocity profile. And contrarily, lower
C
a
will be obtained when cavitation or flow separation appears due to the decrease of density.

The velocity coefficient,
C
v
, compares the effective velocity with the Bernoulli velocity. The Bernoulli velocity is the velocity that will be achieved if all the pressure energy is transformed into kinetic energy without losses. So, this parameter is useful in order to evaluate the pressure or energy losses that occurs in the injection process. These losses will be concentrated mainly in the injection orifices, since it is here that the flow finds the principal section restriction, so the
C
v
value will depend mainly on the nozzle orifice geometry. Although it is important to remember that this coefficient takes into account all the energy losses that take place from the upstream (where the injection pressure is measured) to the downstream (the orifice outlet). So, special consideration must be taken in some situations, for example, when different types of injectors are compared.

sec.title: 3 Experimental Facilities
sec.p: In order to perform this study, a commercial common rail and two experimental set-ups have been used together with a methodology for obtaining the internal geometry of diesel nozzles. A brief description of these tools will be made in this section.

sec.title: 3.1 Internal geometry determination
sec.p: A special type of silicone has been introduced inside the nozzles, as described by Macián et al. [11] in order to analyse the internal characteristics of the nozzles used in the current investigation. The silicone moulds have been visualized in a microscope where several pictures of the most relevant geometrical parameters have been taken. An example of the pictures taken for one of the nozzles used in this study is presented in Fig. 2.

caption.p: Processed images of silicone for nozzle B

sec.title: 3.1.1 Geometry nomenclature
sec.p:
Figure 3 schematically illustrates the most significant dimensions of an injection orifice: inlet and outlet diameters
D
i
and
D
o
, length L, and inlet radius r. From these dimensions the following dimensionless parameters of the orifices are defined.

caption.p: Geometric parameters of an injection orifice

list-item.p:
Length–diameter ratio
L / D = L /
D
o
.

Inlet curvature radius–diameter ratio
r / D = r /
D
i
. This parameter determines the design of the inlet orifice. For sharp edges this value will be zero.

Inlet and outlet diameter ratio
D
i
/
D
o
. This parameter determines the orifice convergence or divergence. This parameter is unity for cylindrical orifices and for convergent orifices it will be greater than one.

sec.p:
To determine the orifice convergence in the literature it is common to use the
k − factor
parameter which is calculated as

However, this parameter has a significant weakness, because it does not distinguish between different sizes of orifices. For example, an orifice with
D
i
= 210 μ m
and
D
o
= 200
μ m
has the same
k − factor
as another of
D
i
= 110
μ m
and
D
o
= 100
μ m
; however, the area variation, and therefore the flow characteristics, in each case are completely different. The most appropriate parameter to evaluate the orifice convergence is the area reduction, defined as [11]

sec.title: 3.2 Injection rate meter
sec.p: Measurements of injection rate were carried out with an Injection Discharge Rate Curve Indicator (IRDCI) commercial system. The device makes it possible to display and record the data that describe the chronological sequence of an individual fuel injection event. The measuring principle used is the Bosch method [12], which consists of a fuel injector that injects into a fuel-filled measuring tube. The fuel discharge produces a pressure increase inside the tube, which is proportional to the increase in fuel mass. The rate of this pressure increase corresponds to the injection rate. A pressure sensor detects this pressure increase, and an acquisition and display system further processes the recorded data for further use. Mass flux signals have been processed using the methodology described in [13].

sec.title: 3.3 Spray momentum test rig
sec.p: With this experimental equipment it is possible to determine the impact force of a spray on a surface. This force is equivalent to the spray momentum flux. Figure 4 shows a schematic illustration of the momentum test rig. Sprays are injected into a chamber that can be pressurized with nitrogen up to 10 MPa, in order to simulate pressure discharge conditions that are representative of real pressure conditions inside the engine combustion chamber during the injection process.

Figure 5 shows a schematic illustration of the spray momentum measuring principle. The impact force is measured with a calibrated piezo-electric pressure sensor in order to measure force. The sensor is placed at 5 mm from the hole exit and its target has a diameter of 8 mm. The sensor frontal area and position are selected so that the spray impingement area is much smaller than that of the sensor. Under this assumption, and due to the conservation of momentum, the force measured by the sensor will be the same as the momentum flux at the hole outlet or at any other axial location, since the pressure inside the chamber is constant and surrounds the entire spray, and fuel is deflected perpendicular to the axis direction.

sec.title: 4 Studied Nozzles and Operating Conditions
sec.p: To perform this study three different one hole axi-symmetric nozzles have been chosen. As mentioned earlier, the orifices are convergent with conical shape; additionally, the nozzles have been manufactured with an aggressive hydroerosion process to round the edges of orifice inlet providing them an inlet radius large enough to avoid separation of the boundary layer at the orifice inlet. Both characteristics, convergent orifices and large inlet radius, will prevent the cavitation phenomenon [14]. Also, it can be expected that these types of orifices have few losses, enabling a large discharge capacity.

On these nozzles the mould silicone technique [11] has been used, with the aim of obtaining the internal geometry of orifices. Results for the three nozzles are summarized in Table 1, while the characteristic of nozzle dimensionless geometric parameters are shown in Table 2. Unfortunately, it has not been possible to obtain a complete mould for nozzle C, so the
D
o
value used in the current research is that supplied by the nozzle manufacturer.

caption.p: Internal geometry of the studied one-hole nozzles
Dimensionless parameters of the studied one-hole nozzles

sec.p: As is shown in these tables, the three nozzles are similar. The unique difference between them is the orifice diameter. The strong orifice convergence and the great inlet radius are noteworthy.

sec.title: 4.1 Operating conditions
sec.p: In the current research the following test plan with four different injection pressures and four different discharge pressures is used. A long energizing time of 2000 bar has been selected, with the aim of achieving stationary values of the injection event when the needle lift reaches its maximum position:

In both experimental set-ups, injection pressure has been measured by means of a piezoresistive high-pressure sensor located at the common rail. Fortunately, since the mass flow of these one-hole nozzles is small (compared to conventional multi-hole ones), pressure loss between the pressure measurement point and the orifice inlet is also small.

sec.title: 4.2 Fuel characteristics
sec.p: A Repsol CEC RF-06-99 diesel fuel was used as fuel in the experiments. The summary of some physical and chemical properties is shown in Table 3.

caption.p: Physical properties of Repsol CEC RF-06-99 fuel

sec.title: 5 Results
sec.p: Figures 6 and 7 show some examples of signals obtained for the momentum flux and the injection rate respectively. In these figures it can been appreciated that the larger the orifice diameter, the higher are the momentum flux and mass flow.

caption.p:
Temporal evolution of the momentum flux;
p
i
= 80
MPa
p
b
= 3 . 5
MPa

Temporal evolution of the injection rate;
p
i
= 80
MPa
p
b
= 3 . 5
MPa

sec.p: Given the large energizing time used, the signals have a large area in which the needle is at maximum lift. To perform the following analysis only this stationary area is considered, from which the momentum flux average values, the mass flow and the respective injection pressures at each point tested are extracted. Therefore, with the aim of avoiding the effect that may cause the needle lift, the initial and final period of the test has been neglected.
In the following section the results for the mass flow, the momentum flux, the velocity, the effective area, and the different coefficients are calculated.

The uncertainty in the determination of the coefficients was estimated using the standard procedure as outlined by Holman [15]. The uncertainty obtained for the discharge coefficient was around 1.5 %, and 1.8 % for the momentum coefficient.

sec.title: 5.1 Mass flow
sec.p: Figure 8 shows the mass flow rate versus square root of pressure drop. Each group of points corresponds to an injection pressure. The grey level distinguishes the different back-pressures, being darker for higher values. The mass flow behaviour is linear with the square root of the pressure drop, as is expected for no-cavitant nozzles. In addition, it can also be observed that the larger the diameter is, the higher is the mass flow.

caption.p: Mass flow rate versus square root of pressure drop

sec.p:
The dimensionless values of these data can be used to calculate the discharge coefficient,
C
d
, which represents the relation between the real mass flow and the theoretical calculated values with pressure involved. Figure 9 shows the discharge coefficient versus the Reynolds number calculated from the Bernoulli theoretical velocity
Re =
u
berno
D
o
/ ν
.
In this figure, a similar behaviour for the different nozzles is observed. Nevertheless, in each of them two zones can be clearly distinguished.

list-item.p:
The first corresponds to low Reynolds numbers (). In this zone
C
d
has a growing trend. It is worth noting how the three nozzles, in spite of being different, collapse into the same zone for the same Reynolds number. This behaviour is a little strange, because the nozzles have different relationship
L / D
. However, they behave similarly [16], so this behaviour may be simply circumstantial.

At high Reynolds numbers,
C
d
reduces its growth tendency showing more stable behaviour except for a slight increase with increasing Re. The
C
d
stabilized value is known as the maximum, or last,
C
du
[17]. This maximum value is different for each nozzle, being greater when the diameter is higher and therefore the ratio
L / D
is lower.

sec.p: This behaviour has been observed on numerous occasions in non-cavitanting conditions [17–20]. The trend change is due to the transition from the laminar regime (in growing zone) to the turbulent regime (in constant zone). The explanation of this behaviour will be discussed later, with more information available on the internal flow.

The differences in the
C
du
are consistent with the results presented by Lichtarowicz [17] for orifices without cavitation. Lichtarowicz found that the
C
du
decreases if the ratio
L / D
increases. This behaviour is due to higher friction losses with the walls if the orifice is longer, and thus higher
L / D
.

sec.title: 5.2 Momentum flux
sec.p: Figure 10 shows the average values of momentum flux. As expected, the momentum flux is proportional to the pressure drop. Additionally, the larger the diameter, the higher the momentum flux.

As in the mass flow case, these data can be converted to non-dimensional values by dividing the real momentum flux by the theoretical value so that the momentum coefficient
C
M
, or moment flux, is obtained. Figure 11 shows the momentum coefficient with respect to the Reynolds number. It can be seen that the behaviour of this coefficient is similar to that of the discharge coefficient, although in this case it is more difficult to distinguish between the two zones since there is no abrupt change in the coefficient trend.

caption.p: Momentum flux coefficient versus Reynolds number

sec.p:
As was the case with the
C
d
coefficient, the
C
M
is greater when the orifice diameter increases (decreasing
L / D
). In this case, this behaviour is reflected in both low and high Reynolds numbers.

sec.title: 5.3 Effective velocity
sec.p: In this section the results for the effective velocity and the velocity coefficient calculated from the mass flow and momentum flux data are presented.

Figure 12 shows the outlet effective velocity versus the square root of the pressure drop. As can be observed, the effective velocity of all nozzles is very similar in all cases. This result is reasonable considering that the velocity depends mainly on the pressure drop. The diameter, or more generally the orifice geometry, will not have a significant effect on the effective velocity, except for small differences that can exist in the velocity coefficient.

Despite the velocity obtained from the three nozzles being very similar, it can be noted that, keeping the pressure drop constant, then a greater diameter means a slight velocity increase. This effect is observed more clearly in the velocity coefficient represented in Fig. 13. The explanation for this effect is related to an increase in friction losses with the walls when the
L / D
ratio increases.

The behaviour of the velocity coefficient is very similar in the three nozzles, following an asymptotic trend in the three nozzles. However, unlike the behaviour of the previous coefficients, in the case of the velocity coefficient it is impossible to distinguish between the two zones named above, showing a similar trend for low and high Reynolds numbers.

sec.title: 5.4 Effective area
sec.p: Figure 14 shows the area coefficient calculated from the effective diameter and geometric diameter as a function of Reynolds number.

The same behaviour of separation into two zones can be observed for all nozzles used in the present research: with low Re, the
C
a
grows with the increase of Reynolds number to a maximum value close to one, after which the
C
a
remains constant forming the second zone. It is noteworthy how a very similar stabilized value is achieved for the three nozzles. The two zones are related to the behaviour observed in the discharge coefficient.

The behaviour of the two zones for the case of the
C
a
coefficient contrasts with the case of the velocity coefficient where no change in these two zones is found.
The two points with strange behaviour for nozzle A (higher back pressure and low Reynolds number) are probably wrong due to some error in mass or momentum flux measurement or an accumulation of both.

sec.title: 6 Analysis
sec.p:
In the absence of the cavitation phenomenon, the value of the area coefficient depends on the velocity profile at the orifice outlet, in such a way that
C
a
will be greater, the more uniform is the velocity profile. The most important factor that will influence the profile characteristics is the flow regime. Figure 15 presents the velocity profiles for laminar and turbulent regimes.

caption.p: Comparison between the velocity profiles for laminar and turbulent regimes at the injection orifice outlet

sec.p:
In the laminar regime, since the flow is not fully developed*, the profile will depend on the thickness of the boundary layer. In the boundary layer the profile is parabolic, while in the central line the velocity is constant. The higher the thickness of this layer is, the less uniform the velocity, and therefore the lower is
C
a
.

On the other hand, in the turbulent regime, the velocity profile will be more uniform than in the laminar case, as a result of transverse momentum flux transport caused by turbulence. Consequently,
C
a
will be greater for the turbulent regime than for the laminar regime and very close to unity.

From the two zones of behaviour observed in the area coefficient (Fig. 14), the zone for high Reynolds numbers agrees strongly with the turbulent regime behaviour, and therefore the
C
a
coefficient is very close to unity.

The other zone, for low Re, has traditionally been associated with the laminar regime, see for example [17, 20]. However, as will be shown, in the low Reynolds number zone the flow is in a transition zone between laminar and turbulent flow.
Let us analyse first the behaviour of laminar regime. The thickness of the laminar boundary layer depends essentially on the fluid velocity and distance covered [21], as

Thus, the greater the velocity, the lower will be the thickness of the laminar boundary layer, while the greater the covered distance, the greater will be the thickness. Another factor with influence is the orifice convergence; considering the fluid acceleration when the orifice area decreases, the thickness of the boundary layer decreases due to this higher velocity.

The ratio between the boundary layer thickness and the orifice diameter
δ / D
, obtained from equation (20), and taking into account the Reynolds number, is

Obviously, considering the velocity profile, the higher this relation, the lower will be
C
a
.

Comparing this ratio with the results obtained in the study of diameter influence (Fig. 14) it is observed that, for all nozzles, when the Re increases the
C
a
coefficient increases too (and decreases
δ
).

However, it is not the same for the influence of the
L / D
ratio. From equation (21), the
C
a
coefficient should be greater for the nozzles with the lowest
L / D
. Yet the results show completely opposite behaviour.
From this analysis it can be concluded that for the Re used in this study the nozzles are not completely in the laminar regime at any point.

Since laminar flow has been rejected, let us see if the flow can be in a transitional regime. In the transition zone between laminar regime and turbulent regime, the flow is characterized by intermittent character. This behaviour is characterized by intermittency factor
γ
, which defines the fraction of time during which the regime is turbulent at a given point. Thus,
γ = 1
would mean a steady turbulent regime and, conversely,
γ = 0
would mean a fully laminar regime.

Considering the comments about velocity profiles and
C
a
for both regimes, laminar and turbulent, an increase in the intermittency factor would imply more time in turbulent flow, and therefore an increase in the area coefficient.

As demonstrated by Rotta’s experiments [22] (referred to in [21]), for inlet duct flow the intermittency factor depends on the Reynolds number and distance covered in the duct. Thus,
γ
will be greater if Re and/or the distance covered
x / D
are increased.

Applying this result to the current study, the behaviour of
C
a
for all nozzles in the low Reynolds number zone is explained (Fig. 14) as follows.

list-item.p:
If the Reynolds number is increased, the intermittency factor is increased in the same proportion. As a consequence,
C
a
also increases.

If the
L / D
ratio is increased, there is a higher distance to develop the turbulent flow. This fact will be reflected in an increase in the intermittency factor at the orifice outlet. Again, as a result of this increase the
C
a
also increases. Figure 14 shows how
C
a
is higher when the
L / D
ratio increases.

The point where the turbulent regime is achieved, which coincides with where the maximum
C
a
is reached, occurs at lower Re when the
L / D
ratio of the injection orifice is increased, since more length is available for turbulence development.

sec.title: 7 Conclusions
sec.p: From the present research work the following conclusions can be stated.

list-item.p:
A study with convergent nozzles with different orifice diameters, and hence different
L / D
ratio, has been performed. Due to the absence of cavitation phenomenon in the nozzles studied, the effect of turbulence has been specifically studied, which otherwise would have been masked.

It has been found that internal flow behaviour can be differentiated into two zones, which correspond to developed turbulent flow at the orifice outlet, and with the transition zone between laminar and turbulent regimes.

When injection nozzle flow is not in the turbulent regime, the discharge coefficient decreases, and spray formation get worse due to the smaller turbulence. So, attention should be paid to the appearance of this behaviour, mainly at low pressure points, by injection nozzle designers or researchers, especially taking into account that diesel injection nozzles are getting smaller and more convergent.

The distinction of both zones has been realized by calculating the area coefficient, since this parameter, in cavitation absence conditions, depends on the velocity profile at orifice outlet,
C
a
being greater as the profile is more uniform. Thus, for the turbulent zone, due to the uniform velocity profile, the
C
a
value is proved to be close to unity. On the other hand, in the transit zone between laminar and turbulent regimes, the
C
a
coefficient is found to be greater as the intermittency factor on the orifice outlet increases, or to put it another way, the more time the flow regime spends in turbulent conditions, the higher is the
C
a
coefficient. The results obtained in this region agree with this theory; obtaining a higher
C
a
coefficient if the Reynolds number and/or the
L / D
ratio are increased, because of the greater intermittency factors in these cases.

Another effect of the
L / D
ratio is the increase of wall friction losses when this ratio is increased; this effect is clearly reflected in the results of the velocity coefficient.

In the laminar regime in fully developed conditions, in a distance far enough from the orifice inlet, the profile will be completely parabolic.
